Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a continuous flow isotope ratio mass spectrometer (IRMS) system for the Organic Geochemistry Core Facility at Brown University
Award.AbstractNarration: This Division of Earth Sciences Instrumentation and Facilities Program award supports acquisition of an isotope ratio mass spectrometer (IRMS) system for climate, environmental, and biogeochemical research at Brown University. The new system will be a critical tool for ongoing and planned research projects of four principal investigators at Brown with demonstrated records of NSF funding, and an incoming new faculty member, as well as for educational and outreach activities. The instrument will be managed and maintained as part of Brownâ€™s Organic Geochemistry Core Facility so that it can serve a large number of domestic and international students, visitors, and collaborators. Investigators and technicians have a successful record of operating and maintaining several mass spectrometer systems in the past 20 years. <br/><br/>The IRMS would be configured for continuous flow (CF) isotope ratio measurement of individual organic molecules that have been selected via gas chromatography prior to inlet to the IRMS. Compound-specific isotope analysis (CSIA) using CF-IRMS is central to deciphering archives of climate, environmental and ecosystem change, gaining new insights to biogeochemical cycles, and fostering inter-disciplinary collaborations. CSIA can be used to better infer paleoenvironmental conditions such as the dominant plant types extant in the past or the structure of food webs in natural ecosystems. Prior to the development and use of CSIA, bulk isotopic measurement of organic matter made up of a complicated mixture of molecules produced by different organisms confounded interpretation of targeted paleoenvironmental processes and conditions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using funds from NSF award 2025125, we ordered the new Delta V plus isotope ratio mass spectrometer suite from Thermo Electron in October, 2020, including a gas chromatograph (Trace GC 1301) and GC IsoLink II, dual inlet module, and a Thermal Conversion Elemental Analyzer (TCEA and interface called CONFLO IV) peripheral. The instrument suite was successfully installed in February, 2021, and has been running smoothly ever since. The GCIRMS system has been used to analyze carbon and hydrogen isotopic composition of individual organic compounds, while the elemental analyzer and interface has been used to measure bulk carbon, nitrogen and hydrogen isotopic ratios of solid samples. The new instrument suite replaces the 20-year old, dysfunctional Delta plus XL isotope mass spectrometer system for climate, environmental, biogeochemical and astrobiological research at Brown University.

Before installation of the new Delta V plus IRMS system at Brown, various research projects have experienced major delays due to problems with the 20-year old Delta plus XL system. Such delays no long exist after the successful installation of the new IRMS instrument suite. Students, postdocs from all five co-PIs of the proposal (Y. Huang, J. Russell, T. Herbert, S. Clemens, D. Ibarra) and visiting scholars/collaborators as well as outside users have been generating data efficiently and publishing their discoveries in a timely manner. The instrument suite has been successfully managed and maintained as part of Brown’s Organic Geochemistry Core Facility by our full-time lab manager Marcelo Alexandre, under the supervision of co-PIs.

We disassembled the failed Delta+ XL instrument into individual parts, to be used for teaching purposes. In spring 2023, Co-PIs Huang and Ibarra will co-teach two courses to graduate and undergraduate students: Environmental Stable Isotopes; analytical techniques for low temperature geochemistry. We will open all components for teaching stable isotope mass spectrometer. We will also use the new GC-IRMS for training students in instrument use and calibration. At Brown, graduate and undergraduate students actively participate in instrument operations to gain hands-on experience. All students and postdocs are allowed to operate the instruments by themselves, so that they will have the ability to run the systems independently in their future positions. The GCIRMS facility also brings national and international collaborations and many visiting scientists come to Brown to do analyses and collaborate. The PIs actively coordinate with Brown’s STEM Outreach office to develop research collaborations.  The instrument has formed an important part of a recently funded NSF-REU site program in our department that collaborates with the Leadership Alliance program to provide research experiences to underrepresented minority students from outside Brown. State-of the art equipment for CSIA will thus have substantial broader impacts for researchers within and outside Brown, including underrepresented groups.
